citation.article-title: Jhaorihella thermophila gen. nov., sp. nov., a moderately thermophilic bacterium isolated from a coastal hot spring
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Jhaorihella [Jha.o.ri.hel′la. N.L. fem. dim. n. Jhaorihella named after Jhaorih, or ‘morning sun’ in Chinese, the name of a coastal hot spring on a small volcanic island (Green Island) in the Pacific Ocean, off the eastern coast of Taiwan, the geographical origin of the type strain].
Cells are Gram-negative-staining, non-motile, aerobic, non-spore-forming irregular rods.
The fatty acid profile is characterized by a large amount of unsaturated (C18 : 1ω7c) fatty acids.
In addition, low amounts of hydroxylated fatty acids C10 : 0 3-OH, C11 : 0 3-OH, C12 : 0 3-OH, C12 : 1 3-OH and C16 : 0 2-OH are detected.
The predominant polar lipids of the type species are phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylethanolamine.
Minor amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol, six unidentified phospholipids and three aminolipids and traces of a glycolipid are also detected.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain of the type species is 64.7 mol%.
As shown by 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, the genus belongs to the family Rhodobacteraceae.
The type species is Jhaorihella thermophila.
